question: Which soil property best indicates high nutrient content?

content.source_1: High soil organic matter both stores plant nutrients and typically darkens mineral soil to a brown or dark-brown/black color.
content.source_2: In temperate croplands, darker brown topsoils usually have higher organic matter and nutrient-holding capacity than pale, leached topsoils.
content.source_3: As a field cue, agronomists commonly use dark-brown topsoil color to judge organic-matter–rich, nutrient-rich surface horizons.
content.source_4: Soil color is controlled by factors like iron oxides, organic matter, and moisture; similar brown hues can occur in nutrient-poor, highly weathered soils, so color alone is not a reliable predictor of nutrient levels across soil types.
content.source_5: Cation exchange capacity (CEC) directly measures a soil’s ability to hold and supply nutrient cations (e.g., Ca2+, Mg2+, K+); higher CEC generally indicates greater nutrient reserves and inherent fertility.
content.source_6: Soil-testing guidelines recommend using quantitative measures such as CEC and nutrient assays rather than color to infer nutrient status, because laboratory metrics are more predictive of nutrient content.
